BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence. Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day after a long period of poor weather.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the regions with a lot of snow and on very steep sunny slopes numerous small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
The wind was moderate in some cases. In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.
Dry avalanches can additionally in some places be released in near-surface layers in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Along the border with Switzerland On very steep shady slopes and above approximately 2500 m the avalanche danger is considerable (level 3).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be good. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation there will be only a slight decrease in the danger of dry and moist avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular on very steep sunny slopes and in steep rocky terrain numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are to be expected as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the sometimes moderate wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases below approximately 2300 m. The soft wind slabs are covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on wind-loaded slopes.
Restraint is advisable on this first sunny day after a long period of poor weather.
Along the border with France On very steep shady slopes and above approximately 2500 m the avalanche danger is considerable (level 3).
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. At elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low altitude only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: During the clear night the natural avalanche activity will gradually decrease.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. Snow slides and dry and moist avalanches are to be expected from the morning.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow-covered wind slabs of last week remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2000 m. These are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from northeasterly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in the afternoon in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. Fresh wind slabs can be released easily.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation avalanches are possible. Especially in steep rocky terrain and on sunny slopes medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase during the day. As a consequence of a moderate to strong wind from northerly directions, soft wind slabs will form in the course of the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. Especially on wind-loaded slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Wind slabs can be released, mostly by large loads and reach large size in isolated cases.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: By Saturday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and older wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and older wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in all aspects in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of a gathering strong wind from northerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day. The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The fresh wind slabs are lying on surface hoar in some places.

Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls visible wind slabs formed. In particular on very steep slopes more mostly small avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The meteorological conditions will foster a strengthening of the snowpack. Below approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind slabs can in some places be released by large loads and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow and on sunny slopes more small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation. These can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases or triggered naturally.
As a consequence of the moderate wind, the snow drift accumulations have increased in size during the last few days. They have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls in all aspects and generally at elevated altitudes. In particular above approximately 2200 m,: The more recent wind slabs are to be bypassed in particular in very steep terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last five days. The snowpack will be well bonded below approximately 2000 m.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. As a consequence of solar radiation the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: By Saturday wind slabs will form in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes. At high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of wind, clearly visible wind slabs will form. In some places wind slabs are lying on soft layers. Moist snow slides are possible below approximately 2000 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a light to moderate wind from northerly directions, mostly small wind slabs will form in the afternoon adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as at high altitude. They will be deposited on soft layers. These are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. Fresh wind slabs can in some cases be released easily. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, in particular on very steep slopes.
In particular on rocky slopes and on very steep slopes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry and wet avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 cm of snow, and up to 20 cm in some localities, has fallen since Monday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level. As a consequence of a sometimes moderate wind from northerly directions, soft wind slabs will form in the course of the day in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches are not to be expected. Wind slabs require caution. In addition the small wind slabs of the last few days in gullies and bowls in all aspects and generally in the high Alpine regions are prone to triggering in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular in the northeast some new snow above approximately 1500 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.
